SENT.plain: A 64-year-old male presented with subarachnoid hemorrhage
Angiography showed a dissecting aneurysm of the right vertebral artery (VA), and severe stenosis of the right internal carotid artery (ICA)
He was treated conservatively in the early stage
Repeat angiography showed enlargement of the dissecting aneurysm of the VA and partial resolution of the stenosis of the right ICA
Intraaneurysmal coil embolization with proximal coil occlusion was performed following a balloon occlusion test
Based on the neuroradiological findings, the stenotic lesion of the right ICA was considered to be due to dissection
Analysis of serial changes in dissecting lesions in the craniocervical arteries is important for the correct choice of treatment, especially in patients with multi-vessel dissections
The surgical options should be determined on an individual basis
